publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

msIdentifier.repository: Bibliothèque nationale de France, fonds Pelliot Koutchéen (Paris)

seg.seg: and ... one should make the remedy of that. And thereupon call the symptoms with respect to the gangrene (?)! This [= boil] [is] to be known [as] Sāṃnipātika [= caused by a combination of disorders]. L(ook) at the symptom of the Dvivraṇīya [= caused by the two kinds of wounds] boil! ...
And now I will tell the remedies. As soon as boils emerge, one should immediately examine [them]; Sesame oil is to be put on [them], [and it is] (to be bound with) a cotton bandage.
Now I will state the remedies.
Hedyotis umbellata, aneth, Symplocos racemosa, Berberis aristata, saffron stigmas, sandalwood: [this is] to be crushed together with sugar ...
to (staunch) [it] perfectly. Caesalpina sappan, aneth, Symplocos racemosa, collyrium, yellow arsenic: [this is to be used] with blood to staunch [it] perfectly. Bandages (??) (have to be made) ...
Symplocos racemosa: [once] finely crushed, [this is to be used] with blood to staunch [it]. Symplocos racemosa, lotus leaves, [a measure of the size of] Dhānyamāṣa ...
Withania somnifera (??), gill [lit. fish ear], cow dung pellet: this [is] to be strewn over [it and] to be bound with a ... bandage ...

[If] (the wound?) would bite the terwe of someone, I will tell the remedy [for that]. Anethum sowa, Acorus calamus, Costus speciosus, the fruit of Aegle marmelos (?), milk, oil, sesame oil: by one (measure this is to be crushed).
I will now state the remedy, a salve for whom the terwe bites. (cf 306)
All this [is] to be cooked together. [If] the wound (?) bites the terwe of someone, [this is] the remedy. Cow dung pellet, gill [lit. fish ear] pellet,
[This is] the remedy, a salve for whom the terwe bites. (cf 306)
... pellet, saffron pellet: this is to be strewn over [it], otherwise these very same [ingredients] are to be smeared cold over [it]. These treatments have (to be made as)

a Dvivraṇīya cure [= related to the two kinds of wounds]. [It is to be used] with blood to staunch [it] perfectly. Now I will tell the Treatise about demons [= Bhūtatantra]. Cardamoms, small cardamoms, Dalbergia sisu, ...
Now I will speak of the Bhūtatantra [book of (demoniac) beings]. (52)
and ..., seed of Pongamia glabra, Ferula asa foetida, Piper longum, Piper nigrum, ginger, saffron stigmas, Acorus calamus, Acacia Lebbek: these remedies ...

pure; [only] a cleaned woman [or] daughter should crush [them]. This [is] the powder. If somebody has been made salturna [= bewitched??], he should bathe with it. Immediately (he will become) pure ...

p.note: An almost complete leaf, about 5 to 6 akṣaras are missing on the right margin. The leaf number is written inside the string hole space, which is rather [7]5 and not 55 (as per Filliozat). This may be a typo in 51.
ṣotarnma seems to be a late plural form of ṣotri 'mark' (instead of ṣotruna).

A separation tāk okne is also possible, but not very likely. Both forms would be hapax; to be sure, kok may be interpreted as a wrong Sanskritization of a Prakrit form from Skt. kotha- ‘sore, gangrene' or 'affliction of the eye' (cf. 313a).
One has to read ṣili, which ought to be a mistake for pili. Sieg's correction of pili into pile is speculative; one can accept pili as nom. plural and construct it with yāmoṣ in a subordinate clause.
Note the virāma sign separating the case suffix in śakkār\•mpa.
śabaraloträ is a single word, which has been wrongly separated by a dot.
The remains of the last akṣara permit a reading kaṭpa(l)\ or kaṭpa(ñ)\. The closest Sanskrit word would be khaṭvā- 'kind of bandage', the borrowing of which would give the nom.pl.
The reading śvakate is superior to ścakate and allows a restoration (a)śvakate to be connected with Skt. aśvagandha- 'Withania somnifera' (otherwise attested by the form TB aśvakānt).

kampāsäṣṣe cannot simply mean 'cotton'; the form kampās in THT 337 a 4 is a mistake for kampāl warranted by the parallel text PK AS 18A and note that TA kappās (via Middle Indic kappāsa- from Skt. karpāsa ‘cotton' refers to the cotton plant rather that the material. On the other hand, the woven cotton is called kenek, TA kanak.

lope is rather a borrowing from Skt. lopa-, which can have the meaning 'hurting, breaking, violation' than a late form of a Tocharian abstract laupe from lup- 'to smear'. Consequently, terwe is rather the direct object (and not an adverb, as supposed by Sieg), whis is proven by the object construction with -ne in the parallel passage in b2. It may refer to a part of the skin (?). 324 interprets the form as 'kind of snake' and translates b2 "I will speak now of a salve, a medicine for whom the terwe bites", but this does not work syntactically.

Instead of naṣṣū one has to read kaṣṣu. The following akṣara before the l\ is hardly a ‹ba›, and it cannot be ‹bā› in the first place, because the long ā-vowel would be written to the right and not on top of the sign. pil can be Skt. bilva- 'Aegle marmelos fruit'.
po is rather the end of an ingredient, and not the word po 'all'.
The process of crushing has apparently to be done by a young girl before her maturation, and if an adult woman has to do it, one has to make sure that she is devoid of menstrual blood.
The reading sal [ṣa]rn[e] by Sieg is impossible, the manuscript has salturna of unknown meaning.

list.item: a1 ṣpä sāṃtke yami-ne • t{u}meṃ no pokkāka ṣotarnma tā kokne • se saṃnipātik kärsanalle • dvivraṇi|dvavraṇi pileṃtse ṣotri pä(lyakas) /// a2 ñake no saṃtkenta weñau • istak yāmoṣ_(Pl.)|yāmoṣ {p}ili lakoy kuñcitäṣṣe ṣalype eneṃ yamaṣṣälle kenekäññe|kenekäṃñe śwele(sa |śanmäṣṣälle) mañciṣṭ|(ma)|ñciṣṭ a3 • pissau • śabaraloträ|śabara«†•»loträ śkwaśko|śwaśko • kurkamäṣṣi ptsāñ • candāṃ • śakkārmpa ṣesa waltsanalle na- /// saitsi|(sai)|tsi a4 śpālmeṃ • || pattaṅk • pissau śabaraloträ|śabaralodrä añcāṃ • gairik yasarsa saitsi śpālmeṃ • || kaṭpa- – /// a5 śabaraloträ|śabaralodrä • lykaśke tsatsāpar yasarsa saitsi • || śabaraloträ|śabaralodrä • uppāläṣṣana piltāsa • dhanyamāṣ /// aśvakānt|(a)|śvakate a6 • läksañña|läksaña klautso • kewiye melteṣṣe ṣpel te śār kätnālle kampāsäṣṣe śwelesa śanmäṣṣälle|śanmäṣä«†ṃ»lle ya- /// (lope) terwe|(te)|rwe b1 ket|ke= tsākaṃ sāṃtke weñau || śatapuṣp (o)karo kaṣṣu pil malkwer ṣalype • kuñcitäṣṣe ṣalype • ṣeme yä(rmtsa waltsanalle) b2 te po eṣe päkṣalle lope • terwe ket|ke= tsākaṃ-ne sāṃtke|sātke • || kewiye melteṣṣe ṣpel läksaññai klautsaiṣṣe ṣpel /// b3 ṣpel gairikäṣṣe ṣpel te śār kätnālle epe no kroścana tonak śār lupṣallona • toṃ prayokänta y(amaṣṣällona) /// b4 dvivräṇikalp yasarsa saitsi śpālmeṃ • || ñake bhūtatanträ weñau || kayast vayast • śāñcapo – /// b5 -po ṣp karañcapij • aṅkwaṣṭ|aṅwaṣṭ • pippāl mrañco • tvāṅkaro • kurkamäṣṣi ptsāñ okaro • śiriṣ toṃ saṃtkenta – /// b6 -ne astare nanāṣṣusa klīye|klyiye tkācer wāltsoy se cūrṇ|curṇ k_use salturna yāmu tākoy tesa nāṣṣi_(Opt.)|nāṣṣi istak ast(are)

An almost complete leaf, about 5 to 6 akṣaras are missing on the right margin. The leaf number is written inside the string hole space, which is rather [7]5 and not 55 (as per Filliozat). This may be a typo in [[Filliozat 1948]]: 51.

Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]
Lines Translation Pages
a2 Now I will state the remedies. 657
b1 I will now state the remedy, a salve for whom the terwe bites. (cf [[Adams, DoT]]: 306) 704
b2 [This is] the remedy, a salve for whom the terwe bites. (cf [[Adams, DoT]]: 306) 704
b4 Now I will speak of the Bhūtatantra [book of (demoniac) beings]. ([[Filliozat 1948]]: 52) 657

a1 and ... one should make the remedy of that. And thereupon call the symptoms with respect to the gangrene (?)! This [= boil] [is] to be known [as] Sāṃnipātika [= caused by a combination of disorders]. L(ook) at the symptom of the Dvivraṇīya [= caused by the two kinds of wounds] boil! ... a2 And now I will tell the remedies. As soon as boils emerge, one should immediately examine [them]; Sesame oil is to be put on [them], [and it is] (to be bound with) a cotton bandage. a3 Hedyotis umbellata, aneth, Symplocos racemosa, Berberis aristata, saffron stigmas, sandalwood: [this is] to be crushed together with sugar ... a4 to (staunch) [it] perfectly. Caesalpina sappan, aneth, Symplocos racemosa, collyrium, yellow arsenic: [this is to be used] with blood to staunch [it] perfectly. Bandages (??) (have to be made) ... a5 Symplocos racemosa: [once] finely crushed, [this is to be used] with blood to staunch [it]. Symplocos racemosa, lotus leaves, [a measure of the size of] Dhānyamāṣa ... a6 Withania somnifera (??), gill [lit. fish ear], cow dung pellet: this [is] to be strewn over [it and] to be bound with a ... bandage ... b1 [If] (the wound?) would bite the terwe of someone, I will tell the remedy [for that]. Anethum sowa, Acorus calamus, Costus speciosus, the fruit of Aegle marmelos (?), milk, oil, sesame oil: by one (measure this is to be crushed). b2 All this [is] to be cooked together. [If] the wound (?) bites the terwe of someone, [this is] the remedy. Cow dung pellet, gill [lit. fish ear] pellet, b3 ... pellet, saffron pellet: this is to be strewn over [it], otherwise these very same [ingredients] are to be smeared cold over [it]. These treatments have (to be made as) b4 a Dvivraṇīya cure [= related to the two kinds of wounds]. [It is to be used] with blood to staunch [it] perfectly. Now I will tell the Treatise about demons [= Bhūtatantra]. Cardamoms, small cardamoms, Dalbergia sisu, ... b5 and ..., seed of Pongamia glabra, Ferula asa foetida, Piper longum, Piper nigrum, ginger, saffron stigmas, Acorus calamus, Acacia Lebbek: these remedies ... b6 pure; [only] a cleaned woman [or] daughter should crush [them]. This [is] the powder. If somebody has been made salturna [= bewitched??], he should bathe with it. Immediately (he will become) pure ...
Bibliothèque nationale de France, fonds Pelliot Koutchéen (Paris)
Georges-Jean Pinault (in collaboration with Melanie Malzahn, Michaël Peyrot)

a1. A separation tāk okne is also possible, but not very likely. Both forms would be hapax; to be sure, kok may be interpreted as a wrong Sanskritization of a Prakrit form from Skt. kotha- ‘sore, gangrene' or 'affliction of the eye' (cf. [[M-W]]: 313a).

a2. One has to read ṣili, which ought to be a mistake for pili. Sieg's correction of pili into pile is speculative; one can accept pili as nom. plural and construct it with yāmoṣ in a subordinate clause.

a3. śabaraloträ is a single word, which has been wrongly separated by a dot.

a4. The remains of the last akṣara permit a reading kaṭpa(l)\ or kaṭpa(ñ)\. The closest Sanskrit word would be khaṭvā- 'kind of bandage', the borrowing of which would give the nom.pl.

a5. The reading śvakate is superior to ścakate and allows a restoration (a)śvakate to be connected with Skt. aśvagandha- 'Withania somnifera' (otherwise attested by the form TB aśvakānt).

a6. kampāsäṣṣe cannot simply mean 'cotton'; the form kampās in THT 337 a 4 is a mistake for kampāl warranted by the parallel text PK AS 18A and note that TA kappās (via Middle Indic kappāsa- from Skt. karpāsa ‘cotton' refers to the cotton plant rather that the material. On the other hand, the woven cotton is called kenek, TA kanak.

b1. lope is rather a borrowing from Skt. lopa-, which can have the meaning 'hurting, breaking, violation' than a late form of a Tocharian abstract laupe from lup- 'to smear'. Consequently, terwe is rather the direct object (and not an adverb, as supposed by Sieg), whis is proven by the object construction with -ne in the parallel passage in b2. It may refer to a part of the skin (?). [[Adams, 2DoT]]: 324 interprets the form as 'kind of snake' and translates b2 "I will speak now of a salve, a medicine for whom the terwe bites", but this does not work syntactically.

b1. Instead of naṣṣū one has to read kaṣṣu. The following akṣara before the l\ is hardly a ‹ba›, and it cannot be ‹bā› in the first place, because the long ā-vowel would be written to the right and not on top of the sign. pil can be Skt. bilva- 'Aegle marmelos fruit'.

b5. po is rather the end of an ingredient, and not the word po 'all'.

b6. The process of crushing has apparently to be done by a young girl before her maturation, and if an adult woman has to do it, one has to make sure that she is devoid of menstrual blood.

b6. The reading sal [ṣa]rn[e] by Sieg is impossible, the manuscript has salturna of unknown meaning.

a1 _ṣ_p_a sā[ṃ]tke yami-ne • tomeṃ no pokkāka ṣotarnma tā kokne • se saṃnipāti_k\• _k_arsanalle • dvavraṇi pileṃtse ṣotri _p_a – /// a2 ñake no saṃtkenta weñau • istak yāmoṣ ṣili lakoyä\ kuñci_t_aṣṣe ṣalype eneṃ yama_ṣ_ṣ_alle kene_k_aṃñe śwele – /// a3 ñciṣṭä\ • pissau • śabara • ○ lot_r_a śwaśko • kurka_m_aṣṣi ptsāñä\ • candāṃ • śakkā_r\•mpa ṣesa waltsanalle [na] /// a4 tsi śpālmeṃ • || pattaṅ_k\• • ○ pissau śabaralod_r_a añcāṃ • gairi_k\• yasarsa saitsi śpālmeṃ • || kaṭpa- –\ /// a5 śabaralod_r_a • lykaśke tsatsāpar yasarsa saitsi • || śabaralod_r_a • uppā_l_aṣṣana piltāsa • dhanyamā_ṣ\[•] /// a6 śvakate • _l_aksaña klautso • kewiye me[lteṣṣe] ṣpe_l\• te śār _k_atnālle kampās_aṣṣe śwelesa śan_m_a_ṣ_aṃlle ya /// b1 rw[e] ke= tsākaṃ sāṃtke weñau || śatapu_ṣ[_p\•] – [karo kaṣṣu pi]_l\• malkwe_r\• ṣalype • kuñci_t_aṣṣe ṣalype • ṣeme y[ä] /// b2 te po eṣe _p_akṣalle [lo]pe • terwe ke= tsākaṃ-ne sātke • || kewiye melteṣṣe ṣpe_l\• _l_aksaññai klautsaiṣṣe ṣpe[_l]\ /// b3 ṣpe_l\• gairi_k_aṣṣe ṣpe_l\• ○ te śār _k_atnālle epe no kroścana tona_k\• śār lupṣallona • toṃ prayo_k_anta [y]· /// b4 dviv_r_aṇikal_p\• yasa○rsa saitsi śpālmeṃ • || ñake bhūtatant_r_a weñau || kayastä\ vayastä\ • śāñcapo – /// b5 po _ṣ_p\• karañcapijä\ • aṅwaṣṭä\ • pippā_l\• mrañco • tvāṅkaro • kurka_m_aṣṣi ptsāñä\ okaro • śiri_ṣ\• toṃ saṃtkenta – /// b6 ne astare nanāṣṣusa klyiye tkācer wāltsoyä\ se curṇä\ k_use salturna yāmu tākoy tesa nāṣṣi istak as[t](·)

a1. ṣotarnma seems to be a late plural form of ṣotri 'mark' (instead of ṣotruna).

a3. Note the virāma sign separating the case suffix in śakkār\•mpa.

a4ff. Note saitsi for saintsi.
